content.webTitle: Defences in disarray as Liverpool steal win over Norwich in dramatic finale

fields.headline: Jürgen Klopp and Norwich’s Alex Neil blame defences after Liverpool’s 5-4 win
fields.bodyText: The recurring thought during this match – apart from “wow!” – was: imagine how good these teams would be if they could defend properly? The managers were quick to turn their attention to the issue after seeing wonderful attacking repeatedly sabotaged by woeful defending. Jürgen Klopp attributed all of Norwich’s goals to Liverpool’s feeble handling of set pieces – although Norwich’s creativity and sharpness were also important factors – and said his team’s vulnerability to them has become a mental problem rather than a technical one. He said constant mistakes are undermining his players’ confidence and triggering a vicious circle of ineptitude – and demanded his players become strong enough to put a stop to it. “It’s like a self-fulfilling prophecy,” Klopp said. “Everybody’s talking about it, we’re thinking about it. You see in a situation and it’s ‘a cross, pap, good’, then ‘OK, second ball’, ‘second ball, oh my God!’. That’s the situation.” The manager said he finds the problem all the more galling because he knows his players are good enough to defend set pieces well – because he used to be able to do so and the former Mainz defender was never as a good as them. “I was an under-average player but if I was good at something it was defending set plays. It’s not that difficult. So we know how to defend. We have to do it now.” Klopp could barely believe his defenders left Dieumerci Mbokani onside following a corner, thereby giving the Congolese striker an opportunity to score Norwich’s opening goal with a splendid backheel from seven yards. Klopp was also aghast Norwich were allowed to build nicely down the right before Wes Hoolahan released Steven Naismith to plunder a fine goal on his debut. And Klopp can only have been exasperated by the witless pair of fouls perpetrated by Alberto Moreno that enabled Hoolahan to put Norwich 3-1 up from a penalty. On the flip side he was delighted with how Liverpool fought back after that. “That was really good football,” he said, although they suffered a relapse in the second minute of stoppage time when they failed to deal with a long free-kick, inviting Sébastien Bassong to hammer a spectacular shot into the net from 20 yards to make it 4-4. It did not seem possible that there could be another twist after that, but Adam Lallana provided one by volleying in the winner two minutes later. What that proved, at least, was that Liverpool do not have difficulty scoring goals even when they start without a classic centre-forward, as they did here, with Roberto Firmino the farthest forward while Christian Benteke began on the bench again. The Brazilian was brilliant and not only because he scored twice. His passing gave his team fluency and incisiveness and his immaculate control helped him bring others into play even though he is far more lightweight than typical target men. “After Manchester United, everybody asked me: ‘What about Firmino, you need a real target striker?’ But he scored two against Arsenal and he scored two here,” Klopp said. According to Klopp, to suggest Firmino is not a striker is to be duped by a narrow definition. “I think it’s a wide spectrum. Roberto is a striker. He’s a very offensive player. A lot of strikers are 1.60 metres or 1.70 metres-something. Leo Messi what is he? Let’s discuss about this. Firmino can play and score goals and he is for us a good option to play with. He is flexible and in brilliant shape. Having the option with Christian, that’s good. We have too many games where I can say: ‘This or this is No1’. We have always to make decisions.” Klopp was particularly pleased with the way Firmino created Liverpool’s second goal, flicking on the ball for the unmarked Jordan Henderson to drive into the net. “I would say we had, this season, 350 times a player in exactly this position but we didn’t play the pass,” he said. “So that’s frustrating for a manager. Then here we played the pass and in this moment I was happier.” Alex Neil was very unhappy. The Norwich manager had been encouraged by the first hour of the match but was left reeling by the blunders that handed the initiative back to Liverpool, most notably Russell Martin’s blind backpass that James Milner intercepted to put Liverpool 4-3 up. “It’s fundamentals that we’re doing wrong,” he said. “How do you stop somebody giving a short backpass to somebody? How do you stop somebody maybe not tracking a runner? We had much more control of the game until 65 minutes. For it to happen so late, when everything was fine basically, is just bizarre.” Neil could at least take satisfaction from the performances of his debutants, with Naismith offering new thrust to the team’s attack, while Ivo Pinto was relatively solid at right-back. Another January recruit, the centre-back Timm Klose, watched from the bench following his arrival from Wolfsburg. After what happened here, he is likely to start soon. There may be many other changes, too. “Certainly after that, there’s no question there’ll be places up for grabs,” Neil said. Man of the match Roberto Firmino (Liverpool)
